div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Lucha, February 8, 1901
div1.p:
The work of the Medical
Congress has demonstrated to
the satisfaction of everyone that
the doctrine of survival of the
fittest germ will be the therapeu-
tics of the future.

The most notable document
read during the convention was
the report of Surgeon Major
Reed, in which he gave results
obtained from the studies and
experiments made at Camp
Columbia by the Yellow Fever
Board. He and his colleagues
have proven co clusively that
the mosquito as a conveyor of
infection is responsible for yellow
as well as malarial fever.
Enlarging upon the discoveries
of Doctor Finlay, the physicians
at Quemados have learned much
that will be of immense assistance
in future attempts to prevent
spread of the disease that has
made Havana a place to be
dreaded and avoided.

Too much credit cannot be
given Dr Finlay and the other
gentlemen who composed the
Board. The former, entirely
unaided, had done much of the
preliminary examination, inves-
tigation and development; basing
his work on the belief that--
experiments in the Ro an Cam-
pagna having demonstrated
culpability of culex anopheles in
propagation of malaria--the germ
of yellow fever could be conveyed
in similar manner, he set about
confirming his theory. So suc-
cessful was he that he not only
was able to prove his correctness
of idea but he discovered the
variety which alone carries the
germ, and has thoroughly learned
its nature, manner of propagation,
habits during life, etc.

The other members of the
Board have worked steadily and
courageously, in spite of the
danger to which submitted. Three
of them were attacked by yellow
fever, one dying, Doctor Lazear,
a veritable martyr to his prof-
ession and the particular cause
in which he had enlisted. His
death was a melancholy subs-
tantiation of the idea, he being
inoculated by the poison from
one of his own mosquitoes.

The study has not nearly ap-
proached its conclusion. The
physicians engaged in it are
agreed that the mosquito is guilty,
but they all believe that fever is
conveyed in some other manner,
as yet undiscovered; whether
infections, contagious, sporadic
or infusoric will be decided in
future.

At any rate, enough is known
to warrant search for an anti-
toxin, as future treatment of the
disease will unquestionably be
by inoculation, as is already the
case with small-pox and diph-
theria.

Therein lies danger, of course.
When Jenna, in Ireland, disco-
vered that varioloid pustules were
found on the bands of the majo-
rity of milkers of cows, he sought
and found the cause on the teats
of the animals themselves. Dis-
covery of the virus led to whole-
sale inoculation of the populace
--and wholesale death. Since
then, science has so subjugated
the virus that vaccination is
simple, the after effect slight, and
immunity guaranteed.

Similary successful have been
experiments with diphtheretic
anti-toxin.

In experimenting for a like cure
or preventative of yellow fever,
Lefevre, Sanarelly and Bellinzangi
have been more or less success-
ful.

Lefevre, in Rio Janeiro, dis-
covered a virus that was ap-
parently efficacious; he reduced
mortality among his patients
from seventy-nine to eight per
cent, but he lost many cases
solely from inoculation.

The serum prepared by Sana-
relli was a failure, and has been
practically abandoned.

Doctor Bellinzangi is now in
Mexico. The Mexican Board of
Health allowed him, six months
ago, to try his serum on a case
considered hopeless; the patient
had become infected in Vera
Cruz, and had, while ill, gone
to the higher altitude of the
City of Mexico, a course in-
variably fatal; congestion had
taken place throughout the mu-
cous system, the kidneys were
practically paralyzed, black vomit
had set in, and it was believed
impossible to save the life. Bel-
linzaghi, not daunted by the
severity of the test, essayed a
cure and was wonderfully suc-
cessful; within four days the
case was pronounced out of
danger. The young Italian then
received permission to continue
use of his serum, and saved
eight-five per cent of his patients,
being given, always, the worst
cases obtainable, in many in-
stances only being summoned
when other physicians were
hopeless.

His serum was so satisfactory
that he was paid the sum of
$100,000 that had been offered
by the Mexican Government for
a cure for yellow fever.

The physicians making a study
of the subject have pretty gen-
erally agreed upon two points;
propagation by means of mos-
quito inoculation, and cure--
ultimately prevention--by serum
inoculation, whether that of Bel-
linzahgi or some future discoverer
remains to be seen.

What has been accomplished
is immensely interesting, and
will prove tremendously benefi-
cial. Not only in treatment of
yellow, but also with other
fevers. There have been many
experiments in search of causes
of disease, and the theory of
conveyance by insect has been
gradually gaining strength. Doc-
tor Griffith, of Kansas City, de-
clared to the Congress that, in
his estimation, the fly is to ty-
phoid what the mosquito is to
yellow fever, an idea that he
absorbed in 1898, since borne
out by his own experiments and
those of others.

Whatever may develop in
future, humanity in general and
Havana in particular owe all
honor and gratitude to the men
who have risked their lives and
devoted their energies to a sub-
ject so vitally important. Whether
or no they finally discover and
establish positive preventative
and cure, to them belongs the
honor of having given to re-
search the trend that unquest-
ionably will eventually bring
about the desired result.
